itemDescription: British military officer for the East India Company's military service during the company's rule in India, the First Anglo-Burmese War and the Indian Mutiny (1801-1872)

wikipedia_page.main: Sir Isaac Campbell Coffin  (bap. 24 August 1801 – 1 October 1872) was an officer of the East India Company's military service who served during the company's rule in India, the First Anglo-Burmese War and the Indian Mutiny. He rose to the rank of major-general after a long career in India.

response: Born in Blackheath, the son of Lieutenant General Sir Isaac Coffin, Clifford Coffin was educated at Haileybury and Imperial Service College and the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich. He was commissioned as a Second Lieutenant in the Corps of Royal Engineers. He served in the Second Boer War and was mentioned in dispatches.
* Isaac Coffin, East India Company Army officer
* Sir Isaac Coffin, 1st Baronet, Royal Navy officer
Sir Isaac Coffin (1759–1839) served during the American Revolutionary War and the Napoleonic Wars and became an admiral in the British Royal Navy.

Some retained the family links to Nantucket after the whaling industry had collapsed and many people had left the island.  In the eighth generation, Elizabeth Coffin (1850–1930), an artist, educator and Quaker philanthropist, was known for her paintings of Nantucket and for helping revive Sir Isaac Coffin's school with a new emphasis on crafts. Among the ninth generation, Robert P. T. Coffin (1892–1955) was an American poet who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1936 for his book of collected poems called Strange Holiness.
*Isaac Coffin (1801–1872), East India Company major general
